title: Facebook could start scanning photo comments to catch groomers, safety head says
text:
Facebook could track comments on photographs as part of a crackdown on grooming, the company’s head of safety has said.

Antigone Davis said the social media giant was testing a number of ways to spot paedophiles attempting contacting children before "harm was done".

The revelations come as the company is facing mounting criticism over its plans to encrypt is messaging services such as Facebook Messenger and Instagram’s direct chat function.

The move, which would mean even Facebook would be unable to see what was being said and sent in its messages, was condemned earlier this month by the Home Secretary Priti Patel as creating a “digital blindspot” for paedophiles and terrorists.

Speaking to the Financial Times, Ms Davis, Facebook’s global head of safety, said the company had been developing ways to scan for suspicious behaviour rather than just looking for and deleting illegal images and content.

Red flags could include the age gap between people messaging frequently, accounts contacting lots of different children or being blocked repeatedly.

She added that the company could also scan comments on photos to look for signs of grooming.
